ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Great class to learn the basics of pathology and different areas of medicine from experts in the field.
PATHOBIOLOGY STUFF!
This class taught me a lot about disease and the body's response to disease.  It also introduced me to histology and clinical presentations.

This is like Med School in a nut shell. Learned about all the possible big diseases of lungs, heart, GI Tract, Brain, Kidneys and about cancer in relation to all of these. Learned about the body's responses to injury on a molecular level.
Great course for developing both the critical thinking of a clinician/pathologist as well as broadening one's understanding of the possible origins and expression of diseases.
I learned a good survey of pathology ranging from cancer to gastrointestinal diseases.
I became more familiar with the general pathology of many different diseases and learned how to approach diagnostics.
I learned the logical thinking of analyzing a medical case and determining cause and effect from this.

Wide range of diseases in various organ systems. Pathology and cell death from a molecular, cellular, tissue, organ, and organism levels. What tools and symptoms doctors use to diagnose disease before and after death. Real case discussions and the opportunity to observe autopsies, organ presentations, tumor boards.
I learned a lot about disease progression and the human body.

I learned so much about the human body. I had never taken an anatomy class before, but the professors went into so much detail that I felt like I learned anatomy at the same time as learning pathology.
Recognizing diseases and their pathologies, as well as developed an overall understanding for the body's response to injury and what consequences those responses can have over time.
foundational understanding of the principles of path-biology

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Great course! Well organized and good feedback given.

The 5 blocks was nice because it allowed you to engage with a  topic without fearing it would slip your memory before the exam.  There is a LOT of info covered in the lectures which makes it kind of difficult to hone in on for the exams.  However, the professors made the tests very fair for the most part and told us what we should focus on.

Strengths: organized into 5 blocks, each with different topics and instructors. Made studying super easy because each exam only covered 4-5 lectures at a time. Instructors were also different for every block, which brought a fresh start 5 times in the semester and kept me engaged and motivated. Focus is always on the big picture, not small details, which helped me stay engaged and just focus on how fun it is to learn the content instead of worrying about details that might be on the exam.
Also gave us the opportunity to observe autopsies and Tumor Boards of the Yale Med School which was a great opportunity.

I think creating more standardization between tests and grading would greatly improve the course since it was quite difficult to improve on future exams when you have a completely different testing format.
I think the team did a great job with teaching and presentation of material, though maybe the structure could be more streamlined across professors.

The course is most challenging because the professors and exam styles are all very different. Each midterm felt like a bit of a surprise. However, the TFs did a fabulous job helping us transition between units. The material was interesting overall and assumed a reasonable amount of prior knowledge.
I loved getting the opportunity to see autopsies. I think it was a great way to engage with the topic and very helpful as a pre-med.
One strength was the engagement for most professors in the course, being highly engaged with the class. The last section of the course exemplified this well.

Strengths  - good structure, 4 non-cumulative in-class exams that cover specific blocks, and a final take-home, open-resource exam. Professors very knowledgeable in their respective fields and encourage questions/participation in lecture. Learn tools, symptoms, and findings that docs use to diagnose and treat disease; opportunity to observe autopsies, organ presentations, tumor boards

Weaknesses- few! some modules had just a little too much material to make the lectures not feel so rushed. exams varied in difficulty
The course content is very interesting. However, the course moves quickly and the exams are difficult and very different from each other.
Some of the lecturers went so fast through the content that I didn't have time to absorb it all, but it was really valuable being able to learn from so many professors in one course.

strengths: covered a variety of different topics and systems, an effective overview, I appreciated that the lectures were recorded this year especially when COVID/other illnesses became an issue a month into the semester

weakness: mixed bag of professors - not all of them were as engaging as others

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes! Great for those interested in medicine and exposure to different fields of science.
yes, very interesting stuff REEEEE

If you don't mind taking a lot of exams and you can keep up with the topics, you will be just fine! I would recommend this course to people who have a strong understanding of anatomy and physiology though because if you haven't taken these, the course moves way too fast to follow along.
Yes, if you want to go to med school and find disease processes interesting, definitely take this course.
Yes, it was an amazing MCDB class that gave a glimpse into the structure of medical school classes / curriculum.
A must-have course for premeds
Yes, as an MCDB elective, particularly if youre interested in diseases or pre-med.
If this student is interested in the medical field, I would recommend this course to them.
yes, it was such a cool course, really liked the block structure and more frequent exams rather than large cumulative tests and a final

Yes, especially if you plan on going to med school. This course covers a lot of material that you'll have to learn eventually, and the autopsy shadowing was excellent and very useful. The content connects well to MCDB core courses, without being repetitive because there is more of a focus on histology and clinical presentation as opposed to molecular mechanisms. Overall this is a solid MCDB elective, although it is a shame it isn't a higher level so that it would be more applicable to the major.
Yes! maybe not the best if you have a busy semester (it'll add 5 exams to your roster!), but it is very informative and applicable for pre-meds
I would recommend it if you dont mind the intense studying required for exams and if you want to go to medical school.
Yes! If you love the human body and medicine you'll like this course. Just be ready to learn A LOT of content quickly.
yes, because it's a great introduction to the medical fields.
Yes! It's a great overview of path-biology
